Only the distinction between the enclitic verb in principal and the non-enclitic (orthotone) verb in dependent clauses, which is observed in Sanskrit‚ is lost in Greek, and here the verb is uniformly enclitic, or rather quasi-enclitic.

A strong confirmation of the theory here given is the lact that the only purely enclitic verbforms in Greek, the present indicative ot εἰμί and φημί, are the only sorms that nowhere exceed two syllables and three morae. λέγω might have been accented like τινῶν, λέγε like τινί, but this was not possible with λέγομεν, λέγετε, λέγουσι. Here, therefore, we have the action of analogy: the forms not capable ol enclisis have necessarily taken the recessive accent as a substitute for enclisis and have assimilated to themselves the remaining forms of their system. φημί, εἰμι’, on the other hand, admit of complete enclisis throughout.
